mn37:3.2: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in the Eastern Monastery, the stilt longhouse of Migāra’s mother.

mn37:3.6: “Sir, how do you briefly define a mendicant who is freed through the ending of craving, who has reached the ultimate end, the ultimate sanctuary, the ultimate spiritual life, the ultimate goal, and is best among gods and humans?”
mn37:4.1: “Lord of Gods, it’s when a mendicant has heard:
mn37:4.3: When a mendicant has heard that
mn37:4.4: nothing is worth clinging on to,
mn37:4.6: Directly knowing all things, they completely understand all things.
mn37:4.7: Having completely understood all things, when they experience any kind of feeling—pleasant, unpleasant, or neutral—
mn37:4.8: they meditate observing impermanence, dispassion, cessation, and letting go in those feelings.
mn37:4.9: Meditating in this way, they don’t grasp at anything in the world. Not grasping, they’re not anxious. Not being anxious, they personally become extinguished.

mn37:4.12: That’s how I briefly define a mendicant who is freed through the ending of craving, who has reached the ultimate end, the ultimate sanctuary, the ultimate spiritual life, the ultimate goal, and is best among gods and humans.”

mn37:7.1: “My good Moggallāna, I have many duties, and much to do,
mn37:7.2: not only for myself, but also for the Gods of the Thirty-Three.
mn37:7.3: Besides, I quickly forget even things I’ve properly heard, learned, attended, and memorized.
mn37:7.4: Once upon a time, a battle was fought between the gods and the demons.
mn37:7.5: In that battle the gods won and the demons lost.
mn37:7.6: When I returned from that battle as a conqueror, I created the Palace of Victory.
mn37:7.7: The Palace of Victory has a hundred towers.
mn37:7.8: Each tower has seven hundred chambers.
mn37:7.11: Would you like to see the lovely Palace of Victory?”

mn37:11.1: Moggallāna approved and agreed with what Sakka said.

mn37:11.5: Soon after Moggallāna left, Sakka’s maidens said to him:
mn37:11.6: “Good sir, was that the Blessed One, your teacher?”
mn37:11.8: That was my spiritual companion Venerable Mahāmoggallāna.”
mn37:11.9: “You’re fortunate, Good sir, so very fortunate, to have a spiritual companion of such power and might!
mn37:11.10: Surely that must be the Blessed One, your Teacher!”
mn37:12.1: Then Mahāmoggallāna went up to the Buddha,
mn37:12.2: bowed, sat down to one side,
mn37:12.4: “Sir, do you recall briefly explaining freedom through the ending of craving to a certain well-known and eminent spirit?”
mn37:12.6: And the Buddha retold all that happened when Sakka came to visit him, adding:
mn37:13.8: “That’s how I recall briefly explaining freedom through the ending of craving to Sakka, the Lord of Gods.”
mn37:14.1: This is what the Buddha said.
mn37:14.2: Uplifted, Venerable Mahāmoggallāna approved of what the Buddha said.
